abstract.p: Yamaha introduces small portable guitar amplifier that packs lots of power; photo (M)

block.p: At first glance, the sturdy little black box with reinforced corners resembles an industrial-strength version of Nintendo's GameCube console (strap handle included). But on closer examination, the volume and tone control knobs and the shiny input jack give away its true purpose: portable guitar amplifier.

Street musicians may no longer need a piece of luggage to take their acts down to the corner. The AA5 Monitor Amplifier from Yamaha is just 6.8 by 6.2 by 6.2 inches and weighs less than four pounds, but it packs teeth-rattling power.

But on closer examination, the volume and tone control knobs and the shiny input jack give away its true purpose: portable guitar amplifier.

Street musicians may no longer need a piece of luggage to take their acts down to the corner. The AA5 Monitor Amplifier from Yamaha is just 6.8 by 6.2 by 6.2 inches and weighs less than four pounds, but it packs teeth-rattling power.
The four-watt amplifier, with dual four-inch speakers, has newly designed digital circuitry that permits it to operate on relatively little electricity, Yamaha says.
The AA5 can run for 60 hours on four AA batteries, or it can be plugged into a standard AC wall outlet.
A more robust version, the BA10, is suitable for bass guitars.
The list price for each amplifier is $120, and they are available through online music equipment vendors and bricks-and-mortar retailers like Sam Ash.

With this bantamweight amplifier, Yamaha says, you can ''jam anywhere.'' Or, if you prefer, you can leave your guitar at home and plug a CD or MP3 player into the AA5 for an instant boombox that can really rock the party.
